I am currently in my final year of studying Philosophy, Politics and Economics at the University of York. While at university, I am working as Political Researcher to Iain Dale, first working on British General Election Campaigns 1830-2019, and on other projects since.
My first professionally published piece of writing was my chapter on Napoleon Bonaparte in The Dictators. I have now been commissioned to contribute to four upcoming books, the next being on Winston Churchill’s first election, Oldham 1899, in British By-elections. Iain and I have also appeared together at literature events, most recently the 2025 Lewes Speakers Festival.
I published my first book, The Modern Prime Ministers, in 2020, aged sixteen, which was followed by I Was The Future Once: A David Cameron Biography in 2021. The books were well reviewed and covered by local media, with my first book acting as a fundraiser for my school’s Sixth Form Centre Project.
Outside of writing, I am passionate about making a difference in my community. I stood in my first election in 2023, aged nineteen, and stood again in 2024, gaining 717 votes. In both elections I was proud to run positive campaigns that focused on the issues that mattered to residents.
Within politics, I have also worked on Local Election Campaigns, General Election Campaigns, and a Conservative Leadership Campaign, starting on work experience and most recently serving as Head of Correspondence. I undertook research work for Katie Lam, now Member of Parliament for the Weald of Kent, and since 2023, have been the Young Conservative Coordinator for my home county of Kent.
In my final year at university, I have also undertaken an internship in finance, and am always happy to speak, and give advice, to other young people regarding careers, whether in politics, the private sector, or even writing, so please do get in touch if that applies!

Local Politics Needs To Attract More Young People
My column in the 30 August edition of the Times of Tunbridge Wells on why we need more young people involved in our local politics, and how we can make it happen.

Today, I am delighted to be formally launching my campaign to be the next Borough Councillor for St John’s by setting out my Plan for St John’s.
At its heart, local politics is about people, and the people of St John’s deserve a councillor who understands the challenges they face in 2023 and knows how to address them.
While some may see my youth as a drawback, I know that we need at least one young person representing the people of St John’s, a ward with numerous primary and secondary schools. As someone who less than a year ago was still at one of those schools, I am well placed to understand the issues of the day.
I’m determined to run a positive campaign, built on a message of change for the people of St John’s. The first step of this campaign is engaging with local residents on my plan for a stronger, safer and more successful St John’s. Please consider reading my plan and feel free to get in touch regarding it. I am full of optimism for the future of our ward, and I believe by working with local residents, we can build a ward that we can proudly hand to the next generation.

Excited to have written the chapter on Napoleon Bonaparte in ‘The Dictators’ by Iain Dale.
To be alongside so many incredible fellow authors in this book, from historians I studied at school to politicians, is a great honour, and a huge thank you to Iain for the opportunity.
The tale of the life of Napoleon is a fascinating one. His rise, fall, then rise again and ultimate final downfall is a story for the ages, while his personal life, as a man who was married twice but had over twenty affairs, means that the chapter is far more salacious than you might expect from a history book! If you are interested in reading about Napoleon, and the sixty-three other dictators covered, ranging from Julius Caesar to Vladimir Putin, the book is available in print in all good bookshops and online along with as an e-book along with as an audiobook.

I Was The Future Once – Revised and Updated
Incredibly, it is now two years since I published my second book ‘I Was The Future Once: A David Cameron Biography’ and in those two years David Cameron has made enough headlines to mean that I felt like the book was in need of an update.

It has been a huge pleasure to work as the Researcher for Iain Dale’s latest book British General Election Campaigns 1830–2019, published by Biteback.
Including essays from Sir John Curtice, Sir Robert Buckland MP, Julia Langdon, Tim Bale and Sir Vernon Bogdanor, among many other fantastic authors, the book serves as a great guide to British elections for the last two hundred years.
The book is available signed by Iain Dale, from Amazon and from Waterstones.
It is also available in many other good bookshops, and as an e-book.
You can read more about my experience helping write this book in this article by the University of York Politics Department.
A huge thank you to Iain for this fantastic opportunity, and I look forward to continuing my work with him on his upcoming books.

Incredibly, it is now two years since I published my second book ‘I Was The Future Once: A David Cameron Biography’ and in those two years David Cameron has made enough headlines to mean that I felt like the book was in need of an update. So, in a manner in keeping with a Taylor Swift fan like myself, today I’m rereleasing the e-book with a new chapter!
The new chapter titled ‘From Statesman to Salesman’ covers Cameron’s post premiership years, most notably the Greensill Lobbying Scandal. It is available right now for free on Apple Books, either via the link to my website in my bio, or by just searching my name or the book title on Apple Books.
Please let me know what you think of the new chapter by rating and reviewing it on Apple Books, along with sharing it with anyone you think would find it interesting. Equally, if you haven’t yet read the rest of the book, there has never been a better time! A particular thank you to the people that I mentioned in the updated acknowledgments section, along with to those I thanked the first time around.
